_feedback.title: Good data quality assessments
_feedback.correct:
There are many ways to assess data quality. Good data quality assessments should be:

  • Evidence based
  • Linked to purpose
  • Proactive
  • Communicated

Click continue to see more

_partlyCorrect.notFinal:

  • Evidence based
  • Linked to purpose
  • Proactive
  • Communicated

Click continue to see more

_items.title: Evidence Based
_items.body:
Data users may tell us about quality problems they have experienced. This anecdotal information is useful but it is not enough for us to fully understand the quality of our data.

Measuring the quality of data using evidence-based criteria means we can:

  • Quantify the quality of data
  • Identify changes in quality
  • Monitor the effect of improvements we make

_items.title: Linked to purpose
_items.body:
It can be tempting to measure everything in a data set without linking measurements to purpose. But this makes it harder to focus improvements on things that will make the most difference. It also makes it harder to understand whether the data is suited to our uses.

Linking quality to purpose helps by:

  • Establishing whether incorrect data will have an impact on the way we use the data set
  • Showing how quality varies for different users
  • Explaining why a quality issue might cause problems

_items.title: Proactive
_items.body:
Waiting until someone finds a quality issue means that it will already be causing problems in your organisation. It’s much better to check quality in data routinely, throughout the data lifecycle.

Measuring quality regularly, before we find problems helps by:

  • Identifying issues before they grow
  • Stopping bad quality data from moving through the data lifecycle

_items.title: Communicated
_items.body:
Assessing quality is only useful if people know the results of your assessment.

Good assessments should be clearly communicated to users. This enables them to:

  • Choose the right data source 
  • Adapt their work to account for quality problems

title: Why does quality matter?
body: We have looked at many different aspects of what matters in data quality. Why do you think it is important to know the quality of the data you use?
instruction: Check all that apply

_items.text: Data needs to be good enough to support decisions.
It is a legal requirement to assess data quality.
I might be using the data in a way that was not originally expected.
I should not use data that is imperfect.
Knowing the data is poor quality means I can work around problems.
Knowing the data is poor quality means I am not accountable for mistakes.

_feedback.title: Why does quality matter?
_feedback.correct:
That's right! Good data quality means that data is fit for purpose. It is good enough, but it does not need to be perfect. 

There is no legal requirement to assess data quality, but knowing the quality of the data means that you know if it is fit for the purpose you are using it for, so that you can work around any quality issues.

_incorrect.final:
Good data quality means that data are fit for purpose. They are good enough, but do not need to be perfect. There is no legal requirement to assess data quality and knowing that data is bad quality does not absolve a user of any responsibility for their decisions based on that data.

Knowing the quality of the data means that you know if it is fit for the purpose you are using it for, so that you can work around any quality issues. Good quality data leads to quality decision making.
_incorrect.notFinal: Not quite! Three of these statements are true, three are false.

_partlyCorrect.final:
Almost! Good data quality means that data are fit for purpose. They are good enough, but do not need to be perfect. There is no legal requirement to assess data quality and knowing that data is bad quality does not absolve a user of any responsibility for their decisions based on that data.

Knowing the quality of the data means that you know if it is fit for the purpose you are using it for, so that you can work around any quality issues. Good quality data leads to quality decision making.
_partlyCorrect.notFinal: Almost there! Three of these statements are true, three are false.

title: True or false?
body: Each card below has a statement about why we must assess data quality. Read each one, and decide whether you think it is true or false.
instruction: Click each statement to see the answer

frontImage.alt: Regulations state that we cannot use data if the quality has not been assessed.

_items.backBody: Regulations do not say this, but you will have better results if you know the quality of your data. If you need to assess data quality in a very short time period, check the DQ Hub's guidance on urgent data quality assurance.

frontImage.alt: You only need to assess the quality of data when you first collect it.

_items.backBody: Assessing the quality of data at collection is important. However, quality can deteriorate at any point in the data lifecycle. It is therefore important to assess data quality throughout the data lifecycle.

frontImage.alt: You have to assess the quality of data every week.

_items.backBody:
You need to assess the quality of your data regularly to ensure that it remains fit for purpose.

How often you assess data quality should be based on how often the data changes. This may include, but is not limited to, any processes that: 

  • Input new data
  • Transform existing data
  • Migrate data to another system or platform

frontImage.alt: You should assess the quality of data whenever you use it for something new.

_items.backBody: The quality of your data might be fit for one purpose, but not for another. When you use an existing data set for a new purpose, you should assess whether the data is fit for that purpose.

frontImage.alt: Data quality assessments can increase efficiency in the long term.

_items.backBody:
Regular, good data quality assessments can feel like a substantial undertaking, but the net benefits make them worth the time.

Knowing the quality of your data can increase efficiency by:

  • Helping to focus your resources on fixing the most important problems
  • Allowing you to work around existing quality issues

frontImage.alt: Regular data quality assessments can support improvements.

_items.backBody:
We know that continuous improvement relies on regular reviews. This applies to data quality too.

Regular data quality assessments not only allow you to identify the causes of poor data quality, but also reveal the impact of your work to improve.

Seeing the improvements you are making in solving data quality problems will give you momentum as you continue to progress towards your data quality goals.

title: Data quality action plans
body: Why use a data quality action plan as the method to assess and improve your data quality? They give you both structure to your assessment and actions to improve.
instruction: Click the numbers to see more

_graphic.alt: Two arrows points towards each other with the words 'data quality action plans' in the middle. The left arrow reads 'Structured assessment of quality' and the right arrow reads 'Actions that will address quality problems'.

mobileBody: Data quality action plans (DQAPs) are an approach that combine a structured assessment of quality with actions that will address quality problems.
mobileInstruction: Read more on what data quality actions plans do.

_items.title: Structured assessment of quality
_items.body: DQAPs are evidence based, linked to purpose, proactive and support clear communication of quality.

_graphic.alt: Structured assessment of quality

_items.title: Actions to address quality problems
_items.body: DQAPs are designed for ongoing management of data quality, not for one-off assessments.

_graphic.alt: Actions that will address quality problems

title: Designing a DQAP
body:
In this module, we will go through the steps for designing a data quality action plan. Remember that it should be evidence based, linked to purpose, proactive and easily communicated​.

​If you manage a data set, think about the steps you would apply to that data.​

If you do not currently manage a data set, think about some data that you are familiar with. It could be something simple like flexi time recording, or a complex data set related to your organisation’s work. ​

Hold on to your example as we will use it later on.

title: What makes data quality action plans effective?
instruction: Click each banner to see more.

_items.title: Link data to purpose
_items.body:
Traditional data quality assessments are comprehensive, but they do not account for different uses of the data. They will rate the data as being the same quality despite different purposes.

A data quality action plan links data quality to your needs by considering the purpose the data is used for.

_items.title: Focus on what matters
_items.body:
Traditional data quality assessments treat all fields of a data set as equally important. This means that your essential data is treated the same way as optional data.

By linking data to how it is used, data quality action plans help you to focus on the quality of your critical data first.

_items.title: Work efficiently
_items.body:
It is easy to waste time and resources by measuring and fixing data that does not have an impact on your work.

Data quality action plans can lead to more efficient, targeted improvements to your data quality.

title: How is it different?
instruction: Click the bar on the left hand side of the image to see more.

first.title: Traditional data quality assesments
first.alt: A figure using a large magnifying glass to inspect some document folders.
first.body: Traditional data quality assessments start by looking at the structure of the data set, then what can be measured in the fields. These tests then add up to a single view of quality in a data set.

second.title: Data quality action plans
second.alt: A figure putting together some building blocks.
second.body: Data quality action plans are formed in the opposite way, starting with the way data is used, working through the structure of the data.

_graphic.alt: square in the middle with other squares all around  and pointing to it

title: Why is purpose vital to your plan?
displayTitle: Why is purpose vital to your plan?
body: It's what enables you to express quality as fitness for purpose and it helps people understand why bad quality data needs to be improved.​

title: What is a DQAP?
body: We looked at the features of data quality action plans. Which of these are parts of a data quality action plan?
instruction: Tick all that apply

_items.text: Actions that will address the causes of data quality problems.
A schedule to measure data quality over time.
A report on the completeness of all of the fields in a data set.
_items.feedback: The data quality measurements made as part of a data quality action plan might measure completeness of your data, but DQAPs deliberately focus only on the important fields in a data set.

_items.text: Measurements to assess the quality of data.
A plan to reach 100% accuracy in your data.
_items.feedback: Perfect accuracy may not be relevant or achievable in any or all of the fields in your data set. DQAPs identify which fields matter, and the quality needed to make your data fit for purpose.

_items.text: A list of records with missing data.
_items.feedback: Data quality action plans are time efficient by only identifying places where incomplete data has a negative impact on your business outcomes.

_items.text: An understanding of how the data is used.

_feedback.title: What's in a DQAP?
_feedback.correct:
Correct! A data quality action plan contains:

  • A set of measurements to assess the quality of data
  • A schedule for measuring quality
  • Results from those measurements over time
  • Identification of root causes for data problems
  • Actions designed to address root causes

_incorrect.final:
Not quite! A data quality action plan contains:

  • A set of measurements to assess the quality of data
  • A schedule for measuring quality
  • Results from those measurements over time
  • Identification of root causes for data problems
  • Actions designed to address root causes
_incorrect.notFinal:
Not quite!

Think about the purpose of data quality action plans, what they measure and why.

_partlyCorrect.final:
Almost! A data quality action plan contains:

  • A set of measurements to assess the quality of data
  • A schedule for measuring quality
  • Results from those measurements over time
  • Identification of root causes for data problems
  • Actions designed to address root causes
_partlyCorrect.notFinal:
Almost there!

Think about the purpose of data quality action plans, what they measure and why.

title: True or false?
instruction: Click each card to see the answer

frontImage.alt: Data quality action plans are a quick fix to an immediate problem.

_items.backBody:
Data quality action plans are a long term solution. 

Quick fixes to data quality are often superficial and do not resolve the underlying issue. This makes them inefficient and costly in the long term.

frontImage.alt: Data quality action plans combine assessment with action.

_items.backBody: Data quality action plans combine a structured assessment of quality with actions to address data quality problems. This creates an approach to data quality management that is evidence based, linked to purpose, proactive and communicated.

frontImage.alt: Data quality action plans assess the quality of data according to how it is used.

_items.backBody:
Data quality action plans start from understanding the uses of data and then assess how data quality impacts outcomes.

They can help you understand if your data is fit for your purposes and your users' purposes.

frontImage.alt: Data quality action plans help to manage data quality in the long term.

_items.backBody: Data quality action plans are a way of ensuring ongoing management and maintenance of data quality. They are not intended for one-off, 'snapshot' assessments.

frontImage.alt: Data quality action plans are aimed at data experts.

_items.backBody: Data quality action plans are intended to communicate data quality in a way that speaks to both strategic leadership and technical data experts.

frontImage.alt: Data quality action plans proactively prevent data quality problems damaging your work.

_items.backBody: Data quality action plans take a proactive approach to data quality by addressing root causes of quality issues. This solves problems with data quality before they have negative impacts on your business objectives.

title: DQAP - Metrics
body: You can quantify metrics in different ways:
instruction: Click on each tab to learn more.

_items.title: Percentages
_items.body:
Here we are referring to what percentage of records meet a certain set of criteria. 

Percentage metrics are very useful where you’re looking at a whole data set. High percentages should describe good data, for example “Percentage of records with a postcode”​.

_items.title: Counts
_items.body:
This is about finding the number of records that meet a certain set of criteria.

Counts are useful where you can only count errors, not good data. Counts should describe bad data, for example “Count of spikes in polygons”​.

_items.title: True/False
_items.body:
These are checks that can be answered with a yes/no for the whole data set.

For example, “record count is within 500 of the previous version”, or “Average of values is within 2 percentage points of the previous version” .

title: DQAP Metrics
instruction: List five ways you would measure these dimensions in your data set​.​

_feedback.correct:
Example measurements: ​

  • percentage of postcodes with a valid format (validity)​

  • count of letters returned as undeliverable (accuracy)​

  • percentage of records with non-null in the details field (completeness) ​

  • percentage of records where date of entry is within 2 days of received date (timeliness)​

  • count of staff IDs that appear more than once (uniqueness)​

  • percentage records where team name corresponds to department in organization structure (consistency)​

_incorrect.final:
Example measurements: ​

  • percentage of postcodes with a valid format (validity)​

  • count of letters returned as undeliverable (accuracy)​

  • percentage of records with non-null in the details field (completeness) ​

title: Using DQAP - Setting thresholds
body: Look back over the tests you have identified for your data quality action plan. Keep in mind that you are measuring whether data is fit for purpose, not whether it is perfect.​
instruction: Pick a few of the tests. What results would you expect to see if the data is fit for purpose?

_feedback.title: Setting thresholds
_feedback.correct:
• Resist the temptation to set your threshold for success at 100% or zero errors. Unless you would consider the whole data set unfit if a single error occurred, these are not realistic targets. ​

  • Keep in mind that there will often be acceptable exceptions. We may expect phone number to be complete, but some people simply have no phone number. ​

_incorrect.final:

_items.title: Measuring your data set
_items.body: Measure your data set against the tests that you have identified and record the results. Store the results with your DQAP in a way that allows you to add future results and monitor change over time.

For illustrative purposes, we are showing a couple of priority parts of a data set with one data item each but in practice a data set may have a number of priority parts and data items.

_items.body: Check that your tests are achievable. Sometimes it is impossible to measure data in the way we intend. If possible, identify alternative ways to measure the dimensions you identified as important.

title: Using DQAP - Root Cause
body: The most effective improvements to data quality address problems as early in the data lifecycle as possible. That means they are fixed for more users and have less chance of reoccurring. To do that well, it’s not enough to understand the quality problem, we have to find out what the root cause of that quality problem is.
instruction: If your data has quality problems, what do you think caused them? If not, think about what could go wrong with your data?

_feedback.title: Dealing with the cause of the quality issue
_feedback.correct:
We could go and fix the bad quality data itself, but that would not stop the same problem happening again in the future. We would waste time and money by fixing the symptoms of the problem, not the cause.​

We need to understand why the problem happened and stop it, before we fix the data.​

_incorrect.final:

_feedback.title: Tackling root causes
_feedback.correct: There is no single right answer to fixing quality problems; the right approach will depend on your organisation and what has caused the problem.​

instruction: What actions would address the root cause you have identified?​

_feedback.correct: Discuss the actions with relevant stakeholders and agree action owners.

_incorrect.final: Discuss the actions with relevant stakeholders and agree action owners.
_incorrect.notFinal: Discuss the actions with relevant stakeholders and agree action owners.

_partlyCorrect.final: Discuss the actions with relevant stakeholders and agree action owners.
_partlyCorrect.notFinal: Discuss the actions with relevant stakeholders and agree action owners.

title: Using DQAP - continuous monitoring
body:
• After you measure your data, compare the results against previous results.​

  • Check that your actions are working and look for unexpected changes in quality.​

  •  This is particularly important if a change is happening to your data processes or IT systems.​

  • ​User needs change over time so make sure your quality checks still link to the purpose of the data. ​

  • If your actions are not effective, check you have identified the root cause and look for other routes to improve quality.​

  • Data quality action plans need to adapt and change to stay relevant. Review your plans regularly.​

title: To summarise
body:
Data Quality Action Plans will help you manage the quality of your data.​

If you choose to use a different method, your assessment of data quality should always be:​

  •  Proactive - measure regularly before you know problems exist​

  •  Evidence-based - do not rely on anecdotal reports of quality, record the results​

  •  Linked to purpose - measure what matters by focusing on the purpose of the data ​

  • Communicated - write down the results and monitor change over time​

title: Test your knowledge
body: There are a number of steps to consider when designing a data quality action plan.
instruction: Tick all that apply.

_items.text: First look at the structure of the data set and what can be measured.
_items.feedback:
This is not the first step although you may wish to look at the data set later. 

You should first establish the purpose(s) that the data is used for.

_items.text: Make a list of the reports that will need to be produced from the dataset.
_items.feedback: This will not help you to determine if the data is fit for purpose and fulfils the aim if the organisation. While reports may be a by-product of the exercise, data exists to help us make the right decisions, policies or services.

_items.text: Identify which parts of the data matter most.
Ask data users about quality issues that they have experienced.
_items.feedback: This is needed but it will give a single view on quality in a data set. You should measure the quality of your data using the relevant quality dimensions.

_items.text: Use quality dimensions that are relevant to a data set.
Percentage is the best metric to help measure data quality efforts.
_items.feedback: You can use different metrics depending on the question you wish to answer. You may use percentages when looking at an entire data set, such as the percentage of records with a date of birth. You may want to use counts when counting errors in a data set. You can also use a 'True/False' check when you are trying to answer a 'yes/no' question like "Homelessness applications are within 5 percentage points of the previous count".

_feedback.title: Designing a data quality action plan
_feedback.correct:
Correct! 

Purpose is at the heart of a data quality action plan. Next we can identify the parts of the data set that matter most. We use relevant data quality dimensions to measure quality and define metrics that check the dimensions.

_incorrect.final:
Not quite!

_incorrect.notFinal:

Think about the link between purpose and measurements and the values you are measuring in the data.

_partlyCorrect.final:

title: Root cause analysis
body:
After a review of patients records at a GP practice, a GP Practice Manager discovers that allergy information for some patients was not filled in. 

To address this data quality issue, the Practice Manager decides to:
instruction: Tick all that apply.

_items.text: Phone or write to the patients concerned to get the information
_items.feedback: While it is wise to do so, it does not get to the root cause of why the information was left blank in the system.

_items.text: Ask GPs how they record this information
_items.feedback: That's right. That will help getting to know whether it is human error.

_items.text: assume that it means 'none' and correct the information in the system.
_items.feedback: No such assumption should ever be made, no matter how well one knows the system.

_items.text: Check if there is any validation rule in the system for this data field.
_items.feedback: Yes, this is one of the routes to looking for the actual root cause.

_items.text: Find out if patients are asked about allergies when they register
_items.feedback: That's a good line of enquiry too.

_items.text: Follow various lines of enquiry to assess the root cause of the problem.
_items.feedback: Yes, following the Five 'Whys' technique will help finding the root cause of the problem.

_items.text: Take remedial action to address the underlying reason of the problem.
_items.feedback: After determining the root cause, document the actions to rectify the quality issue, assign action owners and target dates for completion.

_feedback.correct: That's correct. The Practice manager should follow the five whys to identify the root cause of the problem and take appropriate actions to improve quality.

_incorrect.final:
That's not right. 

The Practice Manager should follow the five whys to identify the root cause of the problem and take appropriate actions to improve quality.
_incorrect.notFinal: That's not right. Think about how you will make enquiries to get to the real cause of the problem and the actions you would take to improve quality.

_partlyCorrect.final: Almost there. The Practice Manager should follow the five whys to identify the root cause of the problem and take appropriate actions to improve quality.
_partlyCorrect.notFinal:
Nearly there. 

Think about how you will make enquiries to get to the real cause of the problem and the actions you would take to improve quality.

title: Practice Learning
body: "Knowledge is of no value unless you put it into practice." - Anton Chekhov.

title: Next Step
body:
Now you can put what you have learnt about data quality action plans into practice.

So choose a small data set that you are familiar with, one that could benefit from some improvements and have some impact.  

And remember:

  • Purpose
  • Priorities
  • Dimensions
  • Measurements

Your data quality action plan should include:

  • The quality measurements (linked to purpose)
  • A schedule for measuring quality
  • The results from the data set over time
  • An identification of the root causes for problems
  • Actions identified to address the problems.

_graphic.alt: Process flow with five steps asking why each time.

title: Explanation of 5 whys
body:
Now that you have identified the problem, ask yourself why that occurred. For example, the location is wrong.  

1st Question: why is location wrong? Answer: The latitude and longitude were interchanged.

Using the answer to the first question, again ask yourself why that occurred.

2nd Question: Why were the latitude and longitude interchanged? Answer: The new data provider supplied the latitude and longitude the wrong way round.

3rd Question: Why did the provider supply the latitude and longitude the wrong way round? Answer: The latitude and longitude was wrongly specified in the data template.  

Keep using the answer to the question as the basis for the next question and continue asking for five times (or more if you need to!). You should reach the root cause of your problem.​

title: Data quality action plan elements
body:
A data quality action plan contains:

  • a set of measurements to assess the quality of data
  • a schedule for measuring quality
  • results from those quality measurements over time
  • identification of root causes for data quality problems
  • actions designed to address root causes

title: Traditional vs DQAP
body:
Data quality action plans take a very different approach to traditional data quality assessments.

Think about:

  • How does your organisation currently manage data quality?
  • Are you getting the full benefits of your efforts?
  • Are you measuring what really matters?
  • Who are your data quality assessment results for?
  • Do leaders across your organisation understand the results?

title: Designing a DQAP
body: In this module we have picked the most important items at each stage. When you create a Data Quality Action Plan, you will repeat this for each priority part of the dataset and each purpose, building out a complete picture of the quality of the data.
instruction: Click the numbers to see more

_graphic.alt: Two arrows pointing towards each other with the words 'Designing a DQAP' in the middle. The left arrow reads 'What we have learnt about designing a DQAP' and the left arrow reads 'Points to remember'

mobileBody: This is a recap of what we have learnt about designing a DQAP and the important points to remember when designing a DQAP.
mobileInstruction: Read more about the take aways of this module.

_items.title: What we have learnt about designing a DQAP
_items.body:
We’ve seen that the purpose is at the heart of a data quality action plan.

From the purpose, we can identify the parts of the dataset that most need to be correct.

We can use the data quality dimensions to define what correct looks like for our purpose.

And we can define metrics that check the dimensions.

This means that our assessment will be:

  • evidence based – we are measuring values in our data​
  • linked to fitness for purpose – we have a clear link between purpose and our measurements​
  • clearly communicated – We can use our purpose to explain why quality matters​
_items.strapline: what we have learnt about designing a DQAP

_items.title: Points to remember
_items.body:
Always remember:​

  • your plans should be proportionate, low risk data needs fewer checks than high risk data​
  • focus on the data that has the most impact on our work ​
  • perfect data is not possible, concentrate on achieving data that is good enough​

title: Defining what good enough looks like
body:
• Setting the right target or threshold for your metrics can be tricky. You need to find a point which allows for data that is atypical, or data that might be going through quality assurance, without making the test artificially easy to pass.
  • Think about the point at which you would caution people against using the dataset. If you have ten thousand customer records, you wouldn’t say the dataset was low quality if ten records were wrong. But if ten percent was wrong, you might be taking urgent action or looking for another source of data.
  • Remember that different purposes will have different quality needs, so keep that in mind when setting your thresholds.
  • Each metric in your DQAP needs a threshold. They will be different depending on the metric, the dimension, and the purpose. Find what works for your dataset, measure your data and see which tests pass and which fail.

_items.title: Identify
_items.body: Quality issues can come in anywhere in the data lifecycle. Explore quality issues along the data journey. Does the data appear the same at all stages of the lifecycle?

_graphic.alt: set of interconnecting hexagons showing different aspects relating to data
_graphic.title: Identify

_items.title: Analyse
_items.body: Finding out where a quality problem occurred can be difficult. Analyse the data further to check how widespread the problem is and whether the incorrect data has any common factors, for example, data from a certain year, from a certain region etc.

_graphic.alt: Man sitting at a desk, arms crossed and looking at some information on a piece of paper
_graphic.title: Analyse

_itemGraphic.alt: Man sitting at a desk with arms crossed and looking at information on a piece of paper

_items.title: Diagnose
_items.body: When we know how widespread a problem is, and where it might be occurring, we can use root cause analysis to identify why. This is a very important step before we can decide the best way to improve quality.

_graphic.alt: Concentric circles with a question mark in the middle
_graphic.title: Diagnose

title: Addressing root causes
body:
Some options for tackling root causes include:​

  • improved training of staff​

  • changing systems to make data entry easier​

  • better guidance​

  •  adjusting automated processes​

  • adding validation to fields​

  •  introducing data standards​

​Cleaning bad data is only cost effective after you have tackled the root cause.​

title: Using DQAP - recording actions
body:
Plan which actions you will carry out. Record them in your data quality action plan and set a date for review.​

​Some actions may need to wait until you have funding in place, or for IT change cycle, in this case make sure they are recorded for future reference.​

If you need to make a business case to carry out improvements, weigh this against the cost of not carrying them out. Remember that your quality tests are linked to the purpose of the data and that organisational outcomes might be at risk if the data is not fit for purpose.​

title: Using DQAP - Repeating measurements
instruction: Click on each image to reveal more information

_items.title: Frequency of measurement
_items.body: The right frequency for re-measuring your data will depend on how your how often your data is updated. For a fast-changing, high impact dataset this may be monthly, datasets with infrequent updates may be measured annually. ​

_graphic.alt: confirmed cases of deaths by country shown on a mobile phone
_graphic.title: Frequency of measurement

_items.title: Quality over time
_items.body:
Whatever frequency you choose, record that decision in your Data Quality Action Plan and make sure you stick to it.​

This will give you a picture of quality over time. You can identify any data quality problems as they emerge, and check that your improvements are working.​

_graphic.alt: Bar charts showing improvement over time
_graphic.title: Quality over time

title: Your data
body:
The data set you use contains a lot of information about road traffic collisions. The fields in the data set are listed below. Each of the data fields has differing levels of data quality. There are different issues present in each of them.

The data set is used for multiple purposes. One of these is to support decisions about what type of road safety measures to introduce and where. Which of the fields are important to this purpose?
instruction: Tick all of the fields that are important for this purpose.

_items.text: Times and dates of RTCs.
Locations of RTCs.
Number of vehicles involved.
Severity of any injuries sustained.
Insurance company payouts.
Details of the vehicles involved.
Weather conditions at the time of RTCs.
Time the emergency services attended an RTC.
Duration of road closures due to an RTC.
The number of RTC witness statements collected.
Names of people involved in RTCs.

_feedback.title: Road safety measures
_feedback.correct: Correct! Some of the fields are directly important for your work on improving road safety. Some of the fields are important for the work that supports the emergency services' resource planning. However, not all of the data in the data set have a direct impact on your outcomes.

_incorrect.final:
Not quite! Not all of the data in this data set have a direct impact on your outcomes. Your needs for this use of the data include:

  1. Knowing how RTCs occur
  2. Knowing where RTCs occur
  3. Knowing how severe the RTCs are
_incorrect.notFinal:
Not quite! Not all of the data in this data set have a direct impact on your outcomes. Your needs for this use of the data include:

  1. Knowing how RTCs occur
  2. Knowing where RTCs occur
  3. Knowing how severe the RTCs are

Not all of these fields are directly linked to those needs.

_partlyCorrect.final:
Not quite! Not all of the data in this data set have a direct impact on your outcomes. Your needs for this use of the data include:

  1. Knowing how RTCs occur
  2. Knowing where RTCs occur
  3. Knowing how severe the RTCs are
_partlyCorrect.notFinal:
Almost! Not all of the data in this data set have a direct impact on your outcomes. Your needs for this use of the data include:

  1. Knowing how RTCs occur
  2. Knowing where RTCs occur
  3. Knowing how severe the RTCs are

Not all of these fields are directly linked to those needs.

title: Getting started: Which elements have you used?
body: While planning your approach to managing data quality, you are using the four elements of good assessments. Which of the four elements of good data quality assessment have you used at this stage?
instruction: Choose which of the four elements of data quality assessments you have used in these parts of the process.

_items.text: Assessing data quality even though stakeholders have not complained about results.
Publishing the reports on data quality alongside the data set.

_feedback.title: Elements of a good data quality assessment
_feedback.correct:
Correct!

Good data quality assessments need to be evidence based, linked to purpose, proactive, and communicated.

_incorrect.final:
Not quite.

Good data quality assessments need to be evidence based, linked to purpose, proactive, and communicated. If you are unsure, take a look back at the content in Module 1.
_incorrect.notFinal:
Not quite!

If you are unsure about each of the four elements, take a look back at the content in Module 1.

_partlyCorrect.final:
Nearly there!

Good data quality assessments need to be evidence based, linked to purpose, proactive, and communicated.
_partlyCorrect.notFinal:
Not quite!

If you are unsure about each of the four elements, take a look back at the content in Module 1.

title: Priority data
body:
The emergency services need information to help them plan their resources effectively. This will help to protect the public and save lives when road traffic collisions occur. From the analyses you do with your data set, the police and ambulance services figure out how many staff they need, where they need them, and when they need them.

You start with thinking about the ambulance services planning their long-term staffing needs to deal with road traffic collisions. To support this purpose of your data, what needs to be right?
instruction: Tick all that apply. The course will continue after you answer this question.

_items.text: Where RTCs happen
When RTCs happen
How severe RTCs are
How quickly RTCs are dealt with
Who the people involved in RTCs are
How much it rained yesterday
Who is responsible for causing the RTC
How expensive it will be to repair damage to vehicles involved in RTCs

_feedback.title: What needs to be right?
_feedback.correct: Correct! Making sure that these things parts of the data set are right will help the ambulance service to plan how many staff they need, in what places, and at what times.

_incorrect.final:
Not quite. In order to plan their staffing requirements to deal with road traffic collisions, the ambulance service need to know where and when RTCs occur, how severe they are, and how quickly they currently respond to incidents.

Click continue to see more.
_incorrect.notFinal: Not quite. The ambulance services need information to plan where staff need to be available, what times they need to be available, and how many need to be available to respond to road traffic collisions.

_partlyCorrect.final:
Almost! The ambulance service need to know where and when RTCs occur, how severe they are, and how quickly they currently respond to incidents to plan their staffing requirements to deal with road traffic collisions.

Click continue to see more.
_partlyCorrect.notFinal: Nearly there! The ambulance services need information to plan where staff need to be available, what times they need to be available, and how many need to be available to respond to road traffic collisions.

title: Five whys
instruction: Use the arrows to scroll through the rest of the five whys.

_items.title: Why is the data entered in the field 'Time of RTC' not always the time the incident occurred?
_items.body: Answer: Because it is not clear to the people entering the data that the 'Time of RTC' field is specifically for the time that the incident occurred.

_graphic.alt: Process flow with an answer step leading into a why, then an answer and another why.

_items.title: Why is it not clear to them?
_items.body: Answer: Because they are not provided with this information before they start doing the data entry.

_graphic.alt: Process flow with an answer step leading into a why, then an answer and another why.

_items.title: Why are they not provided with that information?
_items.body: Answer: Because there is no single, defined standard that all regions work to.

_graphic.alt: Process flow with an answer step leading into a why, then an answer and another why.

_items.title: Why is there no single, defined standard that all regions work to?
_items.body: Answer: Because there are no coordinated superusers or shared guidance to implement this.

_graphic.alt: Process flow with an answer step leading into a why, then an answer and another why.

_items.title: The root cause
_items.body: After following the five whys, you now know the root cause. The data for 'Time of RTC' is failing against this metric because there is no process that ensures all people entering RTC data have the same understanding of what the field means.

_graphic.alt: A person looking through some large binoculars.

title: Elements of a good data quality assessment
body:
So far on your journey towards your data quality action plan, you have:

  • thought about the purposes for which you use your data
  • considered which parts of the data need to be right for one of your purposes
  • decided which data quality dimensions matter for these fields
  • decided on metrics for a field
  • applied these metrics and found a data quality problem
  • done a root cause analysis to find the source of the problem
  • decided on actions to solve the problem

Which of the four elements of good data quality assessment have you used in the following parts of your approach?
instruction: Use the drop down menu to choose an option.

_items.text: Deciding that 'Time of RTCs' is an important field.
Investigating the root cause and deciding an action to take.

_feedback.title: Elements of a good data quality assessment
_feedback.correct:
Correct!

By starting with the purposes you use your data for, you knew that the time of road traffic collisions helps the emergency services plan their staffing. This is an approach that is linked to purpose.

Your root cause analysis of problems with data in this field showed that the real cause is because people inputting data do not have a single standard definition of Time of RTC field, not because the data is missing at collection. This is an approach that is evidence based.

_incorrect.final:
Not quite.

By starting with the purposes you use your data for, you knew that the time of road traffic collisions helps the emergency services plan their staffing. This is an approach that is linked to purpose.

Your root cause analysis of problems with data in this field showed that the real cause is because people inputting data do not have a single standard definition of Time of RTC field, not because the data is missing at collection. This is an approach that is evidence based.
_incorrect.notFinal:
Not quite.

Think about why the time of RTCs is relevant to the way that the data is being used, and what a root cause analysis gives you that accepting popular opinion does not.

_partlyCorrect.final:
Not quite.

By starting with the purposes you use your data for, you knew that the time of road traffic collisions helps the emergency services plan their staffing. This is an approach that is linked to purpose.

Your root cause analysis of problems with data in this field showed that the real cause is because people inputting data do not have a single standard definition of Time of RTC field, not because the data is missing at collection. This is an approach that is evidence based.
_partlyCorrect.notFinal:
Not quite.

Think about why the time of RTCs is relevant to the way that the data is being used, and what a root cause analysis gives you that accepting popular opinion does not.

title: Measurements
body:
In Module 3, we considered six dimensions of data quality. Good quality data is:

  • Accurate
  • Unique
  • Consistent
  • Complete
  • Timely
  • Valid

Which dimensions would you consider important for the fields that you are looking at?

_feedback.title: Measurements
_feedback.correct: There is no single, right answer to this question. There may be one, two, or more data quality dimensions that are important for making your data fit for purpose. Some dimensions can be more difficult than others to measure, such as accuracy. Whichever dimensions are important for your data, ensure that measurements of data quality you make are linked to the purposes you use the data for.

_incorrect.final: There is no single, right answer to this question. There may be one, two, or more data quality dimensions that are important for making your data fit for purpose. Some dimensions can be more difficult than others to measure, such as accuracy. Whichever dimensions are important for your data, ensure that measurements of data quality you make are linked to the purposes you use the data for.
_incorrect.notFinal: There is no single, right answer to this question. There may be one, two, or more data quality dimensions that are important for making your data fit for purpose. Some dimensions can be more difficult than others to measure, such as accuracy. Whichever dimensions are important for your data, ensure that measurements of data quality you make are linked to the purposes you use the data for.

_partlyCorrect.final: There is no single, right answer to this question. There may be one, two, or more data quality dimensions that are important for making your data fit for purpose. Some dimensions can be more difficult than others to measure, such as accuracy. Whichever dimensions are important for your data, ensure that measurements of data quality you make are linked to the purposes you use the data for.

Some dimensions can be more difficult than others to measure, such as accuracy. title: Metrics
body:
You have considered your purposes, you have thought about what parts of your data need to be right, and you have decided on data quality dimensions that matter for your purposes. You decide to focus first on making sure that data about when road traffic collisions happen is right. In this example scenario, we will focus on measurement of just one field.

Which metrics could you use to measure validity and consistency for the data recording the time that RTC incidents occurred?
instruction: Tick all that apply.

_items.text: 'Time of RTC' is at least 5 minutes earlier than the 'Time emergency services attended'
The hour value for 'Time of RTC' is less than 24
Data in the 'Time of RTC' field is not formatted as plain text
Every record has an entry in the 'Time of RTC' field
No two records have the same figure for 'Time of RTC'
Online national news articles have also reported the incident

_feedback.title: Measurements and metrics
_feedback.correct:
Correct!

For the Time of RTC to be valid we would expect the data in this field to be formatted as a time, and the value must be between 00:00 and 23:59. We also expect internal consistency in our database, so the time the incident occurred must be earlier than the time the emergency services attended.

_incorrect.final:
Not quite.

For the Time of RTC to be valid we would expect the data in this field to be formatted as a time, and the value must be between 00:00 and 23:59. We also expect internal consistency in our database, so the time the incident occurred must be earlier than the time the emergency services attended.
_incorrect.notFinal:
Not quite.

Three of these metrics would measure validity or consistency. The other three might measure different dimensions, or might not be appropriate metrics for this data set.

_partlyCorrect.final:
Almost!

For the Time of RTC to be valid we would expect the data in this field to be formatted as a time, and the value must be between 00:00 and 23:59. We also expect internal consistency in our database, so the time the incident occurred must be earlier than the time the emergency services attended.
_partlyCorrect.notFinal:
Almost.

Three of these metrics would measure validity or consistency. The other three might measure different dimensions, or might not be appropriate metrics for this data set.

title: Investigating data quality problems
body: What action would you take next after finding this problem?
instruction: Choose an action to take. The scenario will continue after you have answered the question

_items.text: Where would you start?

_options.text: Write a business case to acquire a more advanced data entry system
Investigate how widespread the problem is
Hire more staff to clean the data

title: Starting the five whys
body: You need to find the root cause of this data quality problem so you can take the right action to fix it. What would you ask first? Choose a useful question to start your root cause analysis.
instruction: The course will continue once you have answered this question.

_items.text: Why was this not spotted earlier?
Why is the Time of RTC data invalid for some regions?
Who is to blame for this problem?
How much will it cost to fix this problem?

_feedback.title: Why is my data bad quality?
_feedback.correct:
Correct!

You are asking a helpful question to start your investigation: Why is the Time of RTC data invalid for some regions?

_incorrect.final:
Not quite. 

The most important thing is to focus on finding out how to fix the data quality problem. Assigning blame does not help to fix the data, and you cannot calculate costs until you know the root cause that needs to be fixed.

title: Deciding on actions
body: Which actions would be most effective to solve the problem?
instruction: Choose two actions

_items.text: Report immediately to the senior manager
Discipline data entry staff for the errors
Create and share a single guidance document that defines standards for data fields
Train some regional superusers to support data entry staff with their traning
Change the data entry system to have strict validation rules
Purchase a new data cleaning programme to clean the invalid data

_feedback.correct:
Correct. 

The root cause of the problem is that training and guidance for data entry staff is not consistent and needs to be improved.

Changes to the system or purchasing IT solutions can be expensive, and would not solve this problem.

_incorrect.final:
Not quite. 

The root cause of the problem is that training and guidance for data entry staff is not consistent and needs to be improved.

Changes to the system or purchasing IT solutions can be expensive, and would not solve this problem.

title: Putting the plan together
body: You think about the things that you need to make your data quality action plan. What will you need to include?
instruction: Think about what other things matter for this data quality action plan.

_feedback.title: Making your data quality action plan
_feedback.correct:
There is no single, correct way to manage your data quality. Data quality action plans will look different for every data set, but the approach will always be linked to purpose, evidence based, proactive, and communicated.

Remember a data quality action plan contains:

  • a set of measurements to assess the quality of data
  • a schedule for measuring quality
  • results from those quality measurements over time
  • identification of root causes for data quality problems
  • actions designed to address root causes

_incorrect.final:
There is no single, correct way to manage your data quality. Data quality action plans will look different for every data set, but the approach will always be linked to purpose, evidence based, proactive, and communicated.

Remember a data quality action plan contains:

  • a set of measurements to assess the quality of data
  • a schedule for measuring quality
  • results from those quality measurements over time
  • identification of root causes for data quality problems
  • actions designed to address root causes

title: Content
body: This course contains four modules.
instruction: Click on each section to find out more.

_items.title: Good data quality assessments
_items.body: What they look like and why they matter. This module is for everyone who has completed the Introduction to data quality course.

_items.title: Why Data Quality Action Plans
_items.body: How they can guide you from assessments to more effective improvements. This module is for everyone who has completed the Introduction to data quality course and has an interest in applying data quality improvements.

_items.title: Designing a Data Quality Action Plan
_items.body: Steps to create a good data quality action plan for your data. This module is for people who manage a data set, or multiple data sets.

_items.title: Using a Data Quality Action Plan
_items.body: How to use the plan you have designed and take the right actions to tackle quality problems. This module is for people who manage a data set, or multiple data sets.

title: Navigation
body:
